newsitem.title: USA: Micron shares off with chip prices falling.
newsitem.headline: Micron shares off with chip prices falling.

text.p: Micron Technology Inc. shares fell in heavy trading Monday on signs of a further decline in prices of memory chips, its main product.
Micron slid $1.25 to $22.375 on the New York Stock Exchange, where it was among the most active issues in early afternoon trading.

Semiconductor analyst Charles Boucher of UBS Securities said prices of four-megabyte dynamic random access memory chips, the most commonly used memory chip in personal computers, have fallen in recent days to $1.90 in several Asian markets from about $2.50 just two weeks ago. In Japan they are selling for $2.00, he said.
Analysts had previously said DRAM prices of $2.50 were close to being less than the variable cost of making them.
Boucher said it was not clear if the decline in DRAM prices was the reason Micron's stock was lower.
Prices for memory chips have fallen since the winter and Micron's shares have dropped in tandem with them, from a 52-week high of $94.50 to as low as $16.625.
Micron and other memory chip makers have been converting their production lines to manufacture 16-megabyte DRAMs, which are being installed in newer personal computers.
However, prices for 16-megabyte DRAMS have also fallen to about $9 to $10 currently from about $11 to $12 two weeks ago. They had dropped to as low as $8 on the spot market.
